{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3150393,"name":"Andy Gasser","username":"gdefender","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-22T05:36:38.109Z","cooked":"

I’m running into a strange odometry / pose estimation problem.

If I start at zero and I push the robot forward along the carpet 5 meters, my odometry measure is within 5mm of actual. However, when I push the robot back what odometry thinks is 5 meters I come up 10 cm short of the starting point. This behavior is pretty repeatable. If I then push the robot forward 5 meters and back, odometry will read zero about 20 cm short of the starting point.

I can’t figure out why this would be happening. My module states use falcon built-in encoder values, multiplied by a constant coefficient to convert to meters or radians, depending on the motor. The swerve modules are SDS Mk4i’s. I could understand the reading being off due to play in the modules, but the error would be the same each time and not compound.

I’m using the SwerveDrivePoseEstimator, but I’m not passing in any vision measurements at this time.

Here’s a link to the code. The interesting bits are the PoseEstimatorSubsystem, SwerveSpeedController, and SwerveSteerController.

GitHub

GitHub - STMARobotics/frc-7028-2023

Contribute to STMARobotics/frc-7028-2023 development by creating an account on GitHub.

Carpet ply (EDIT: the term is “pile”) is directional. We ripped our hair out in 2018 dealing with this problem. Though, 10cm/5m seems too high to be a result from the carpet.

Easy enough test to run though. Repeat exactly what @gdefender did originally, but with the robot facing the opposite way. If “forward” (based on robot orientation) is still seeing mm-level accuracy, then it’s definitely not a carpet direction issue.

Not a bad theory, and it could be a contributing factor. But we ran multiple tests over a couple hours. Most were in the same direction, but a couple were reversed.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-02-22T06:05:57.918Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":111,"readers_count":110,"score":22.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":427691,"topic_slug":"swerve-odometry-accurate-forward-coming-up-short-in-reverse","display_username":"Andy Gasser","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":5628,"username":"s_forbes","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s_forbes/{size}/1822_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44380,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-odometry-accurate-forward-coming-up-short-in-reverse/427691/4","custom_user_title":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3150400,"name":"","username":"s_forbes","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s_forbes/{size}/1822_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-22T06:15:14.997Z","cooked":"

I’d suggest some more testing with varying the direction of the test to rule out the carpet, and also vary whether the robot is pushed manually or driving under its own power. If it’s a carpet/wheel effect, it tends to be worse with smaller diameter wheels, which is unfortunate if you are using swerve.

We encountered this last year, it was the carpet. We saw approximately 10% difference between directions (moving 5 meters back and forth resulted in 5cm of error)
